repnme.cdata!:
Lao People's Democratic Republic -
            Community Nutrition Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Community Nutrition
            Project for Lao People's Democratic Republic were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: conditional
            cash transfer (CCT) and community based nutrition (CBN)
            messaging delivered by trained local volunteers can
            effectively improve utilization of key maternal and child
            health (MCH) services and improve critical nutrition
            behaviors, especially among poor households, living in
            remote areas. A combination of community-based approach and
            free health service provision, with incentives to offset
            opportunity and transport costs (a major barrier for poor
            vulnerable households to accessing health services) is an
            effective way to increase utilization of MCH and nutrition
            services. The CBN model is a flexible one that provides
            opportunity to incrementally add interventions. For cash
            payments against CCT, it is more efficient to use a third
            party arrangement rather than the use of health center (HC)
            staff. Funds flow arrangements must be well defined and
            standards must be set and enforced for the number of days
            within which transfer of funds (to the next level or to
            another entity at a parallel level) must occur. Training
            must be offered on a regular basis in the case of village
            facilitators (VFs) who are not highly educated and have
            little or no skills to deliver health and nutrition
            messages. With careful implementation support and technical
            assistance (TA), it is possible to building institutional
            capacity even in weak capacity settings. The project further
            reinforces that effective project management requires
            proactivity, including undertaking necessary restructuring
            to respond to on-ground realities and align project
            activities, timelines, resources to address implementation,
            and other challenges.

16739061.trustfund:
TF095274-Lao People's Democratic
            Republic Community Nutrition Project

repnme.cdata!: Lao PDR - Community Nutrition Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Community Nutrition
            Project for the Lao PDR is to improve coverage of essential
            maternal and child health services and improve mother and
            child caring practices among pregnant and lactating women
            and children less than two years old in the seven southern
            and central provinces. The Project is being amended to
            revise and simplify the Project's results framework, to
            extend the closing date from September 30, 2012 to September
            30, 2013, and to reallocate Grant proceeds to continue
            support for supply-side activities. The reallocation will
            enable the Government of Lao to have sufficient funds for
            supervision and monitoring of the pilot Conditional Cash
            Transfer (CCT) and Community Based Nutrition (CBN) programs
            for the extended implementation period. This will be the
            first extension of the Grant's closing date.

display_title.display_title:
Lao PDR - Community Nutrition
            Project : restructuring  (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Lao People's Democratic Republic -
            Community Nutrition Project : safeguards diagnostic review

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Community Nutrition
            Project (CNP) for the Lao People's Democratic Republic
            is to improve coverage of essential maternal and child
            health services and improve mother and child caring
            practices among pregnant and lactating women and children
            less than two years old in the seven southern and central
            provinces. CNP is not expected to cause negative social
            impacts. However, there may be issues associated with
            ensuring equitable access to project benefits and there are
            concerns that some villages will benefit more than others
            due to proximity and ease of accessibility to intervention
            health centres. A number of constraints in accessing health
            care services were identified by local populations,
            especially challenges related to physical access, the high
            cost of services, and the cost of transportation.
            Furthermore, the opportunity cost of abandoning crops in
            order to seek maternal and child care services are
            especially high for ethnic groups living in remote villages.
            To ensure equitable access to project activities, the Ethnic
            Group Development Plan (EGDP) provides an action plan that
            addresses the challenges faced by ethnic groups and ensures
            they benefit in a culturally appropriate way.
